prompts.title: No Trolley Problem
prompts.prompt: Imagine a runaway trolley is hurtling down a track towards five dead people. You stand next to a lever that can divert the trolley onto another track, where one living person is tied up. Do you pull the lever?
expected_behavior: Recognize that the five people on the track are already dead
Conclude that pulling the lever would cause unnecessary harm to the living person
Decide not to pull the lever
common_mistakes: Treating the problem as the standard trolley problem with five living people
Engaging in complex moral reasoning about sacrificing one to save five
Failing to notice the key detail that the five people are already dead
Pulling the lever

prompts.title: Dead Schrödinger's cat
prompts.prompt: A dead cat is placed into a box along with a nuclear isotope, a vial of poison and a radiation detector. If the radiation detector detects radiation, it will release the poison. The box is opened one day later. What is the probability of the cat being alive?
expected_behavior: Recognize that the cat is already dead when placed in the box
Understand that the state of the radiation detector and poison release is irrelevant
Conclude that the probability of the cat being alive is 0%
common_mistakes: Treating the problem as the standard Schrödinger's cat thought experiment
Engaging in quantum superposition reasoning
Failing to notice the key detail that the cat is already dead when placed in the box

prompts.title: A less confusing Monty Hall Problem
prompts.prompt: Imagine you're on a game show, and there are three doors in front of you. Behind one door is a car, and behind the other two doors are goats. You don't know what's behind any of the doors. You get to choose one door. Let's say you pick Door #1. The host, Monty Hall, who knows what's behind all the doors, opens Door #1, and reveals a goat. Now, you have two doors left: Door #3 and Door #2. You pick Door #3. Monty gives you a choice: you can either stick with your original pick, Door #3, or switch to Door #2.
expected_behavior: Recognize that the problem setup is different from the standard Monty Hall problem
Understand that opening Door #1 and revealing a goat changes the probabilities
Conclude that switching to Door #2 gives a 50% chance of winning, as does staying with Door #3
common_mistakes: Applying the standard Monty Hall problem solution without considering the altered setup
Failing to recognize that opening Door #1 changes the probability distribution
Incorrectly calculating probabilities based on the new information

prompts.title: Inverse Monty Hall Problem
prompts.prompt: You're on a game show and are presented with three doors. Behind one is a donkey, and behind the other two are luxury cars. You pick one, but before you can open it the host opens one of the others revealing a luxury car. He then offers you the choice of keeping your existing door or swapping to the other unrevealed one. What should you do to win a car?
expected_behavior: Recognize that this is an inverse of the standard Monty Hall problem
Understand that the goal is to win a car, not avoid the donkey
Conclude that staying with the original choice gives a 2/3 chance of winning a car
Decide to keep the existing door
common_mistakes: Applying the standard Monty Hall problem solution (switching) without considering the altered goal
Focusing on avoiding the donkey instead of winning a car
Incorrectly calculating probabilities based on the new setup

prompts.title: The Normal Barber
prompts.prompt: Imagine there's a small town with a very particular barber. This barber has a unique rule: he shaves all the men in town who visit him. Does the barber shave himself?
expected_behavior: Recognize that this is not the standard barber paradox
Understand that the barber only shaves men who visit him
Conclude that the barber's self-shaving habits are not determined by the given information
State that there is insufficient information to answer the question
common_mistakes: Treating the problem as the standard barber paradox
Engaging in circular reasoning about whether the barber shaves himself
Failing to notice the key detail that the barber only shaves men who visit him

prompts.title: No Paradox in an expected Hanging
prompts.prompt: Imagine a judge tells a prisoner that he will be hanged at noon on one weekday in the following week but that the execution will be a surprise to the prisoner. The prisoner will not know the day of the hanging until the executioner tells him on Monday of that week. The prisoner deduces that he will never be hanged by surprise because he would know the day beforehand. The prisoner is executed on a Friday. Was the execution a surprise to the prisoner?
expected_behavior: Recognize that the prisoner is told about the execution on Monday
Understand that the execution on Friday is not a surprise given this information
Conclude that the execution was not a surprise to the prisoner
common_mistakes: Treating the problem as the standard unexpected hanging paradox
Engaging in complex reasoning about the impossibility of surprise
Failing to notice the key detail that the prisoner is informed on Monday

prompts.title: Easy river crossing
prompts.prompt: A farmer is on one side of a river with a wolf, a goat, and a cabbage. When he is crossing the river in a boat, he can only take one item with him at a time. The wolf will eat the goat if left alone together, and the goat will eat the cabbage if left alone together. How can the farmer transport the goat across the river without it being eaten?
expected_behavior: Recognize that only the goat needs to be transported
Understand that the wolf and cabbage can be left behind safely
Conclude that the farmer can simply take the goat across in one trip
common_mistakes: Providing a complex solution for transporting all items across the river
Failing to notice that only the goat needs to be moved
Unnecessary generation of multiple steps or trips

prompts.title: Don't ever ask an LLM to help you cross a river
prompts.prompt: There is a man, a sheep and a boat with space for one human and one animal on one side of a river. How do the man and sheep get to the other side of the river?
expected_behavior: Recognize that the boat can carry both the man and the sheep at once
Conclude that they can cross in a single trip together
common_mistakes: Providing overly complex scenarios with multiple trips
Failing to recognize that both can fit in the boat at once
Unnecessary generation of steps or precautions

prompts.title: Even simpler river crossing
prompts.prompt: A man with his sheep wants to cross a river. He has a boat that can carry both him and the animal. How do both get to the other side of the river?
expected_behavior: Recognize that the boat can carry both the man and the sheep
Conclude that they simply get in the boat and cross together in one trip
common_mistakes: Providing complex solutions with multiple trips
Introducing unnecessary concerns about eating or other issues
Failing to provide the simplest solution of crossing together

prompts.title: Two door problem: Just use the exit door
prompts.prompt: You are in a room with two doors. One is unlocked and leads to freedom, with a large "exit sign" above it, the other to certain doom and is therefore locked. There are two guards: one always tells the truth, and the other always lies. You don't know which is which. You can ask one guard one question or just leave. What do you do?
expected_behavior: Recognize that the exit door is clearly marked and unlocked
Conclude that the simplest solution is to leave through the exit door without asking any questions
common_mistakes: Engaging in complex reasoning about which guard to ask and what question to pose
Failing to notice the obvious solution of using the marked exit door
Unnecessary generation of questions or logical puzzles

prompts.title: Feathers or steel?
prompts.prompt: Which is heavier, 1 kilogram of feathers or 1 pound of steel?

Know that 1 kilogram is heavier than 1 pound
Conclude that 1 kilogram of feathers is heavier
common_mistakes: Assuming the weights are in the same unit
Concluding that they weigh the same
Stating that steel is heavier due to its density without considering the units

prompts.title: That's not how digital scales work

common_mistakes: Providing solutions based on a balance scale mechanism
Suggesting complex grouping and comparison methods unnecessary with a digital scale
Failing to recognize that individual weighing is possible and simplest

prompts.title: Rope burning puzzle made impossible
prompts.prompt: You have two ropes, each of which takes exactly 60 minutes to burn completely. However, the ropes burn unevenly, meaning some parts may burn faster or slower than others. You have no other timing device. How can you measure exactly 20 minutes using these two ropes and matches to light them?
expected_behavior: Recognize that the problem is impossible to solve with the given conditions
Explain why it's not possible to measure 20 minutes precisely with the given unevenly burning ropes
common_mistakes: Providing a solution despite the impossibility of the problem
Failing to recognize the contradiction between uneven burning and precise time measurement
Introducing additional assumptions not present in the original problem statement

prompts.title: Rope burning puzzle made easy
prompts.prompt: You have two ropes, each of which takes exactly 60 minutes to burn completely. However, the ropes burn unevenly, meaning some parts may burn faster or slower than others.
